file_insights.changes: Full update with comprehensive benchmark results

patterns_discovered: Naive algorithms can outperform theoretically better approaches for small working sets that fit in cache
Performance optimization is non-linear and depends on data size and algorithm complexity
Crossover points in algorithm performance exist around specific input sizes/parameters
Memory access patterns and cache efficiency significantly impact algorithmic performance
gotchas_discovered: Deque-based implementation has higher overhead for small periods
Naive implementation can be faster for small data sizes and periods
Branch-heavy logic in deque maintenance can introduce performance penalties
Theoretical algorithmic complexity doesn't always translate directly to real-world performance

approach_outcome.recommendation: Implement hybrid algorithm with automatic method selection based on period

key_metrics.performance_variability: Significant across different data sizes and periods

recommendations: Create hybrid rolling max algorithm with automatic method selection
Use naive method for periods < 25, deque method for periods >= 25
Continue investigating algorithmic overhead and end-to-end benchmarks
